abstract.p: Roberta Smith reviews Meg Webster's installations at Paula Cooper Gallery (S)

Paula Cooper Gallery 534 West 21st Street, Chelsea Through Oct. 14

The pluses and minuses of Meg Webster's current show are blatant: one installation piece is excellent, the other isn't. Excellent is ''Warped Floor,'' a 20-foot-square, 6-foot-high undulating surface made of largish terra-cotta squares set in sand and supported by a wood infrastructure. It suggests an enormous mountain desert compressed to bonsai scale -- or a particularly huge Charles Simonds work. Even when you walk on it, which is allowed, you seem to be viewing it from a great distance.

The second work, which is two pieces, accomplishes no such magical atmosphere or perceptual inversion. ''Long Pool'' is a Jacuzzi-size reservoir of water surrounded by a dense array of tropical plants, including orchids, ferns, a pineapple tree and a water lily. A narrow channel connects it to a second pool, ''Interacting Falls: Plain and Shooter.'' The title explains the difference between the streams of water emptying into the pool from characteristically low-tech apparatus overhead, while also suggesting a sexual pun.

With all the spritzing and greenness, these pieces have their soothing aspects; with a little polishing they would be at home in a shopping mall. But mainly they heighten the experience of the terra-cotta terrain of ''Warped Floor,'' making it seem even stranger, like a mirage encountered at the edge of a jungle.
